author: Massimiliano Vitelli
title: Sospetti maltrattamenti a un cavallo, la campionessa di equitazione Charlotte Dujardin perde i giochi olimpici | Vanity Fair Italia
text:
Un palmares ricchissimo, nel quale ci sono anche primi posti a Campionati del Mondo e a Campionati d’Europa, che le è valso due onorificenze: Ufficiale dell’Ordine dell’Impero Britannico nel 2012 e Commendatore dell’Ordine dell’Impero Britannico nel 2016.
Ma nella sua carriera non ci sono solo premi, applausi e luci, ma anche diverse ombre.
Charlotte Dujardin, oggi nei guai e fuori da Parigi 2024, era già stata squalificata dall’Europeo 2019 dopo che al temine di una gara il suo cavallo risultò ferito ad un fianco e sanguinante.
Ed ora ci risiamo. In un video spedito all’Autorità Giudiziaria si vede chiaramente l’amazzone londinese frustare con violenza alle zampe - per ben 24 volte in pochi secondi - un cavallo montato da un ragazzo di 19 anni.
Il filmato, trasmesso integralmente durante la trasmissione televisiva Good Morning Britain dell’emittente iTV (e poi riproposto da tutte le televisioni del Regno Unito), ha creato sgomento e rabbia nell’opinione pubblica spingendo la Federazione Internazionale degli Sport Equestri (FEI) a squalificare immediatamente il capitano della Nazionale britannica per almeno sei mesi.
Una presa di posizione forte anticipata dalla stessa Dujardin che, probabilmente consapevole di ciò che le stava per accadere, si era già autoesclusa da Parigi 2024.
«Sono profondamente triste e mi vergogno», le parole di Charlotte Dujardin, «sono stata protagonista di un brutto episodio durante il quale ho commesso un errore di valutazione. Non è quello che si vede nel video il mio modo di allenare i cavalli, avrei dovuto dare un esempio migliore ai miei allievi. Sono ovviamente a completa disposizione della Federazione Internazionali degli Sport Equestri per tutti gli accertamenti che si riterranno necessari».
“Condanniamo qualsiasi condotta contraria al benessere dei cavalli», la dichiarazione ufficiale della FEI – «e abbiamo regole rigorose per affrontare tale comportamento. Il nostro impegno nel garantire i più alti standard qualitativi di benessere equino e sportività rimane incrollabile».
Vincendo una medaglia a Parigi, Dujardin sarebbe diventata l’atleta donna britannica più medagliata nella storia delle Olimpiadi.

title: Anthony Aranda emocionado por su boda con Melissa Paredes
text: En Vivo Anthony Aranda fue consultado por sus planes de matrimonio con Melissa Paredes. [Anthony Aranda](https://www.americatv.com.pe/noticias-de-anthony-aranda-50039) estuvo en MQM para ser parte de una secuencia de baile y no pudo esquivar las preguntas acerca de su boda con [Melissa Paredes](https://www.americatv.com.pe/noticias-de-melissa-paredes-9430). Y es que en los últimos días la feliz pareja reveló que ya tienen fecha para su boda religiosa y están con todos los preparativos. "Hace casi un año le pedí la mano y le dije que en 1 año nos casábamos (...) La cosa es que estamos súper felices y emocionadísimos por cada momento. No soy de emocionarme mucho, pero cada cosita que escogemos para nuestro día es súper lindo", acotó. Anthony Aranda no pasó desapercibido el regreso de Melissa Paredes como [Patty](https://www.americatv.com.pe/al-fondo-hay-sitio/patty-reaparecio-y-encaro-joel-desplante-no-tienes-perdon-noticia-150054) en la temporada 11 de Al fondo hay sitio y [ le dedicó unas tiernas palabras](https://www.americatv.com.pe/mas-espectaculos/al-fondo-hay-sitio-anthony-aranda-celebro-melissa-paredes-regreso-patty-noticia-150070) a través de las historias de su cuenta oficial de Instagram. author: Sloane Perron
title: Anna Maria College Awarded $1 Million DOJ Grant to Launch School Safety and Mental Health Initiative
text:
Anna Maria College has been awarded a $1 million grant from the Department of Justice to implement the Supportive School Safety Intervention Project (SIP) in Central Massachusetts. This transformative initiative aims to increase school safety by addressing mental health challenges and promoting supportive learning environments for students, educators, parents, and communities.
The project, funded by the Bureau of Justice Assistance’s STOP School Violence Grant Program, will enable Anna Maria’s recently established Mental Health Training Institute to provide free, evidence-based mental health and safety training to school personnel, law enforcement officers, students, and community stakeholders. Over the next three years, Anna Maria plans to train 1,500 individuals in mental health first aid, reaching schools in four districts initially and expanding outreach across Central Massachusetts.
“This generous grant enables us to tackle the root causes of violence by focusing on mental health and community collaboration,” said Mary Lou Retelle, President of Anna Maria College. “It builds on our extensive effort over the past two years to provide Mental Health First Aid Training to public safety professionals across the Commonwealth. More than 3,000 police, fire, EMT, and corrections officers were involved in that initiative funded through Congressionally Directed Spending from Senators Markey and Warren. Through this new grant, we are committed to helping schools and communities build safer and more supportive environments.”
The SIP program is set to launch with outreach in Worcester County, beginning in the Auburn, Leicester, Oxford, and Spencer-East Brookfield school districts. Mental health is not one size fits all. As a result, SIP will provide individualized training and resources based on the specific needs of each school district thereby allowing schools to pinpoint and directly address the unique mental health needs of their student populations. The initiative will support these communities by delivering mental health first aid training, creating stronger ties between schools and local organizations, and providing ongoing resources through Anna Maria College’s Public Safety programs and Mental Health Training Institute.
“We are grateful to the Bureau of Justice Administration for this award, which is a testament to the significant community impact of our academic programs, particularly our newly established Mental Health Training Institute and our public safety programs,” said Dr. Chioma Ugochukwu, Senior Vice President for Academic Affairs.

author: thenewsroom@metroland.com (Metroland Staff)
title: Canada Post strike and layoffs: What Statistics Canada data reveals about labour disruptions in Canada
text:
As Canada Post’s unionized workers hit their second week of being on the picket line, the company has confirmed it’s temporarily laying off postal workers.
Employees with the Canadian Union of Postal Workers have been on strike since Friday, Nov. 15.
It means no regular mail or parcels have been delivered to customers.
A mediator was sent by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service on Tuesday, Nov. 19, to try and get some agreement between union representatives and management, however the mediator has temporarily stepped away, citing both sides are still too far apart.
On Nov. 25 the union issued a notice that “Canada Post has been calling CUPW members to lay them off.”
“Rather than make an effort to bargain good collective agreements that meet the needs of postal workers and the public, Canada Post has dug in its heels,” the union posted on its website. “Canada Post refuses to drop its proposed rollbacks that will create a second class of worker and undermine good, full-time jobs.”
Recent disruptions
While Canadian businesses and residents deal with the lack of postal delivery service, this isn’t the first strike that has impacted some routines.
The Liquor Control Board of Ontario (LCBO) went on strike on July 5, after contract negotiations broke down between the company and members of the Ontario Public Service Employees Union (OPSEU). The strike ended on July 22.
And Air Canada had to cancel some flights in September as the agency prepared for a potential strike with more than 5,200 unionized pilots.
Air Canada was finalizing contingency plans to suspend most of its operations beginning Sept. 15.
Fortunately, a last-minute deal was reached prior to pilots walking the picket line, and service resumed as normal.
According to a Nov. 26 release from Statistics Canada, just under one-third of Canadian workers — approximately 5.3 million people — were in a collective bargaining unit in 2023.
Public sector workers were five times more likely to be in a union than private sector employees, StatsCan said.
And in 2023, there was a significant number of workdays lost due to strike action.
“Going on strike is a final option available to unions when negotiations with management reach an impasse,” the data collector said. “Strikes were much more prevalent in Canada during the 1970s and early 1980s.”
In 2023, the number of person-days not worked due to labour disputes rose to its highest level since 1986, at 6.6 million days — mostly due to strikes in the educational services and public administration sectors.
And Statistics Canada also found that the number of people in a union has fallen since 1997. Back then, 21.3 per cent of workers were in a union. Last year, there were 15.5 people in a union.
However, another blast from the past may be playing a role in some of the current labour unrest.
Back in the 1970s and 80s, inflation was actually a contributor.
“In 1980, for example, the annual average rate of inflation was 12.5 per cent,” StatsCan said.
With lower rates that followed, another spike has been seen in the past few years. The Consumer Price Index rose by 6.8 per cent in 2022 and saw a 3.9-per cent increase in 2023.
“Higher inflation may therefore be related to the highest level of labour disruptions we have seen in almost four decades in 2023.”
For more information about labour union statistics, visit statcan.gc.ca.

title: Статус базовой школы РАН присвоен сельской школе Оренбургской области | Science | Seldon News
text: Деминская школа в Пономаревском районе стала первой и пока единственной школой в Оренбуржье, получившей престижное звание базовой школы Российской академии наук. Такое решение приняли на расширенном заседании комиссии РАН в Москве. Василисе Скворцовой, директору Деминской школы удалось обосновать потенциал учебного заведения и соответствие его высоким критериям проекта. Базовые школы станут центрами допобразования и площадками для развития молодых ученых.
